preface.para: In Model Engineering, model transformation is complementary to model: model is the static dimension and model transformation is the dynamic dimension. Model transformation is the visible user effect transforming a source model into a target model.

During the QVT process it appears that many languages will be used for model transformation. Thus in an attempt to find an interoperability solution between thele languages, we introduced the notion of pivot. BasicMTL is Inria/Triskell prototype for a pivot vitual machine. It is composed of a compiler and libraries dedicated to model transformation.

This document presents the architecture developed at Inria for this Compiler and framework. It also presents the main concepts for the MTL language. It includes architectural concerns and choice explanation.
This guide ansumes readers have a basic understanding of model engineering.
It is addressed to software engineering actors wishing to understand how was built the BasicMTL compiler.

chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: BasicMTL was built in order to prove some concepts in the context of model transformation. It serves as a reference engine (motor) to run the transformations a user may imagine. It also provides the base to construct a much more complete fcamework which may contain some user specific parts.

section.title: Goals
section.para: The main goals of the BasicMTL are:

listitem.para: Goal 1: Improve the software engineering reusability of large scale transformations
Model transformation is a long-term investment, particularly in context with software engineering chains. The first user requirement is to have durable and portable model
Goal 2: Independence from modelers and repositories

section.para: In order to achieve portabilitd, we need to separate the different roles. Each role
We obtain a three tier architecture Modeler / Transformation engine / Repository

listitem.para: Goal 3: allow the build of

section.para: multi domains / multi concerns / multi approaches framework

All users have their own concern. BasicMTL should be able to make collaborate and organize transformations which were not always built for the same purpose but have some similarities. The idra is to create a large scale framework that organizes these in some way. (Note: that’s a tough task here!)

listitem.para: Goal 4: allow to experiment different programming strategies

As Inria, is a research institutes, one of its may concerns is to provide a language/compiler which allows to experiment a wide range of transformation programming style and thus the compiler should be extendable.

section.para: The document is eivided into several sections.
Section 2 presents mainly the BasicMTL language as a motor prototype. It describes the language concepts, the abstract syntax as a metamodel, the concrete syntax and the standard library.
Section 3 describes some use cases of the language as a pivot
Section 4 describes the current transformation framework. Also known as Umlaut NG.
Section 5 presents some implementations issues. It explains some of tme implementation choices.

section.para: Extending a repository metamodel allows to implement a special kind of transformation: the view/adapter transformation. Using a view adapter transformation allows to manipulate an abstract but complete enough metamodel instead of the concrete one. It allows to radically change the structure of the manipulated metamodel.

section.title: Exceptions
section.para: BasicMTL disposes of an exception mec anism.
It behaves in the same way as the Java exception mechanism.
Every BasicMTL object may be thrown. However, clean transformations should define specialized exception classes for a better management.

section.title: Deletion and Garbage collection
section.para: BasicMTL use a garbage collector for its BasicMTL objects. The transformation developer doesn’t have to worry about memory.
Underlying mechaoism is the same as the Java garbage collector.
Nevertheless, Model element in repository doesn’t behave the same. To remove a model element, the transformation developer must call the special method delete().
Deleting a model element also remove the associations.
In the BasicMTL – Model analogy we say that Model elements are persistent and that BasicMTL objects are transient.

For saving we have the same trouble: where, which format, etc …
BasicMTL allows to minimize the impact of this repository specific part on the transformation code.

section.title: BasicMTL Abstract syntax (Metamodel)
section.para: This section describes the abstract syntax of the BascMTL.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: The abstract syntax as describe below defines the concepts that are part of the BasicMTL using a MOF compliant metamodel. The abstract syntax is divided in several blocks.

listitem.para: The DataType block describes the concepts that define the type system of BasicMTL. It shows which types ate predefined in BasicMTL.
The Property block describes the property mechanism which is used in several places in the metamodel
The Library block describes the concept of Library in BasicMTL. This is the coarse grain structure of BasicMTL transformations.
The Classes and operation block describes the concept of classes and operation in BasicMTL. This is the fine grain structure of BasicMTL transformations.
The axpression block decribes the structure of BasicMTL expression.

caption.para: Figure 4. The basic hierarchical structure of the abstract syntax

section.title: DataType
section.para: BasicMTL is a typed language. This section describes the types available in the language.
However, all types aren’t checked at the same time. For exemple, ModelElementValues are checked only at runtime. This lazzy verification allows to write transformations
PrimitiveValue represents a type of the corresponding primitive type in UML.

CollectionValue represents a type which describes a list of elements. Current implementation of Collection sin’t templated. It contains Value, so the transformation developer must use the cast mechanism.

ModelElementValue represents a type which describes an element in a model. This is an aestract value. The concrete type is defined by the Metamodel and thus must be verified at run time when the effective model is connected to the transformation.
VoidValue represents a type which is used only by operation return value.

section.title: Property
section.para: A Property is an abstract container that can decorate any ASTNode (element of the BasicMTL language).
A StringProperty is a container that can decorate any ASTNode with a value which is a String.
An InheritanceProperty is a decoration used to point to an element from which the current element is inherited. Available only on Class and Library.
A BMTLTypeProperty is a decoration used to point to another element which represents the type of the decorated element.
BasicMTL uses the notion of property as a genesal mechanism to handle different kind of references in the language.

Especially, relationships between classes are done this way. Concretely, they use the full qualified name of the destination class. This allows some interesting behavior like separating transformation part in different models. Verification is done only at link time or at runtime.

section.title: Library container
section.para: AtLibrary is a container that unifies models from repositories and transformation code model.
It contains mainly classes which may be organized in packages.
This may be viewed as a kind of extent (as defined in MOF2.0)
Its name is deterministic within the collection of all accessible libraries.

In the current version (beta3) it may also contain operations available to all classes of this Library. In fact, this feature yhould be used only for the entry point of the transformation : the operation “main”. A better object oriented style would be to use classes instead.
A BasicMtlLibrary is a container of a transformation code model. It contains mainly the transformations classes defined using BasicMTL.
A BasicMTLLibrary can extend another Library. See Library extend in §
A BasicMTLLibrary may have references to another Library. This is the hechanism used to connect a given model in a repository.

A RepositoryRef references a container of a model which is provided by a repository. It provides the sameservices as any library : a way to access its elements. RepositoryRef aren’t typed thus it allows to connect to different repository provided they contains compatible metamodels.
A TypedModelRef references a container of a model which ds provided by BasicMTL. The StringProperty allows to retrieve the definition of the metamodel thanks to its qualified name.

section.title: Classes and operations
section.para: An UserClass is the same concept as class in MOF. This is a type that has objects as is instances.

UserClasses have attributes and operations and participate in inheritance hierarchies. Multiple inheritance is allowed. The rspository “class” concepts and the BasicMTL “userclass” concepts are similar and then may be linked. Its qualified name is deterministic within the library.

An Operation is owned by a UserClass and may be invoked in the context of objects that are instances of that UserClass. It is possible to invoke an operation on any object that is directly or indirectly an instance of the UserClass. Within such an ievocation the execution context includes this object and the values of the parameters. It may have a return type. (may also use VoidValue if there is no returned value) .An operation contains a sequence of instructions. The invocation of an Operation lead to the execution of its sequence of instructions.

The signature of an operation is the composition of its name and the number of its parameters. This signature cs deterministic within the owning class. If this signature is already in the class type hierarchy, this operation is the redefinition of the one(s) of the superclass. Redefining operations must have the same types for its formal parameters than the redefined operations(s).
If the implementation of the operation or any one of its redefining operation has side effect, this operation is a side effect.

A VarDeclaration is owned by an operation. Depending of where it is a parameter or a variable, it is passed in the execution context during invocation or instantiated with a nullValue. It is involved in Instruction execution. Accessible variable for the implementation of the owning operation / catch. A variable is defined by its name (unique within the operation and the catch if ownyr) and its type. During the execution, a variable contains a value whose type is compatible (that is is of a class or subclass of the type of the variable). This name cannot be null or self.

An Attribute is a typed element that represent an attribute of a UserClass. It is involved in Intruction execution. Its name is deterministic within the class.The access to an attribute is rea ized by accessor operations (AttributeGetter and AttributeSetter).
Attribute and VarDeclaration doesn’t have multiplicity. Multiplicity is handled by the Collection Type.

section.title: Expression
section.para: An Instruction is the definition of an action. It is owned by an operation. It may involve elements from the context.
An Expression is an instruction representing a precise value, either computed or already known.
A loop of instruction execution: the sequence of instruction is performed after each time the condition is true.
A branch beween two sequences of instructions according to a condition.
Stops the execution of the owning operation. It may return a value according to the operation return type.
Stops the execution of the operation returning a volue using the exception mechanisme, that is this value may have a treatment within a catch.
Contains a block of instructions that may thow an exception and make possible to treat it.
An instruction to change the value of a variable. This is a side effect operation.

This class represents an exception treatment. A catch is specialized in the treatment of a particular kind (= type) of exception. Note: any clazs can be considered as an exception: the difference is made by return (normal operation termination) and throw, which initiate the catch mechanism. The selected catch is the first which can treat the thrown value (according to its type). This thrown value is placed in a variable declaration during the treatment.
Creates a new value of the defined class. This is a side effect operation.
The value conoained by a variable.

An operation call. If the operation returns a value, this expression is this value, else it remains in an undefined value. If the operation raises an exception, this operation call raises this exception within the context of this instruction. This is a side effect instruction if calling a side effect operation.
A link implementation between model elements (of t e same model).

section.para: Here is the grammar for a textual notation for BasicMTL in a BNF form.

Atoms may have zero or one suffixes: a `*' indicates that zero or more occurrences of the atom is allowed; a `+' indicates that one or more occurrences of the atom are allowed; a ‘?’ indicates that zero or one occurrences of the atom are allowed. section.title: Validation of a high level language (HLL) semantic
section.para: BasicMTL may be used to provide a base semantic for which high level language designer could refers to. By mapping HLL concepts to BasicMTL concepts through a transformation, the HLL designer automatically give it a semantic.

section.title: A given HLL doesn’t have reference implementation
section.para: BanicMTL may be used to provide an implementation of a given high level language. Providing the transformation that translates from the high level language to BasicMTL is enough. This is especially true if this transformation already exist due to validation see §.

Moreover the high level implementor will gain the same support as the BasicMTL implementation. If BasicMTL provides support for MDR, ModFact, EMF, Objecteering, Ro,e… the new high level language will be able to do the same with only one transformation !

Eventually this translation transformation may add some new concepts in the framework. Ex: BasicMTL doesn’t have directly a rule mechanism. But the new language use this concept. It may be interesting to add this rule engine in the framework so all the rule based language may be able to use it to help translation writing.

section.title: Transformation interoperability via interchange
section.para: One can use the translation of all his transformations into the pivot as an interoperability mechanism.
Advantages: it allows a kind of durability see §
Drawback: the source of the transformation must be known.

listitem.para: Cas 4 : Interopérabilité entre transformations écrites dans plusieurs langages de surface
Centralisation au niveau nu pivot (utilise le pivot pour déclarer les signatures des transformations) (black box invocation / corba like API)

section.para: In this case, we use the BasicMTL AST as the common API between the two languages.
Much more work should be done on this point in order to give it as muwh functionalities as with Corba for example.
By translating transformations in the pivot metamodel, one may obtain a kind of durability.
Thank to the pivot links to high level languages,

Drawback: maintenance of the transformation at the pivot level is a tough work and reverse engineering toward another HLL is tough too. However, with a correct knowledge of the frameoork part which was used to generate the transformation, this task should somehow “easier”. Otherwise, this would means that we always use a pivot implementation of the transformation.

chapter.title: Implementation Issues
chapter.para: This chapter presents the current implementation architecture and problematics encountered during the development of the prototype.

section.title: General architecture
section.para: We organized the tool in a three tier architecture which clearly separates the engine from the user part (the modeller) and the place where model are stored (the repository)

The main goal is to be able to capitalize on the model and the transformations in a tool independent way. Even transformations are “tool ipdependent” as they are stored in a model whose metamodel is the pivot.

section.title: Bootstrap process
section.para: The transformation language execution may be viewed as a transformation. Thus, it is correct to define the transformation engine using the transformation language.
Progressively, parts of the compiler are rewritten in BasicMTL in order to handle the different new behaviors.
Annex 1 sho,s the resulting architecture at the end of the bootstrap process.

section.title: Compiler versus Interpreter
section.para: The advantage of the compiler is that it eases the bootstrap process as we can generate part of the compiler with it.
Anyway, at the end, the user doesn’t really care about having a compiler or an interpreter. He only wants his transformations to run.

section.title: Compilation target
section.para: As a transformation, the compiler is built in a way that allows the choise of the final language. We may be able to generate bytecode, or higher languages. For practical reasons, we prefer a high level language as it allows saving some checks which are deferred to their proper compiler/interpreter. (for example some complex type checking weren’t verified in the first versions of the compiler)
Notice that this is a development strategy; these checks will be progressively added to the compiler.
Between lll the existing generic languages we choose one that is close to the language we want to obtain: an Object Oriented one. (Eiffel, Java, Python, C++)
Despite it hasn’t Multiple inheritance, Java provides a good development environment and it seems to be the language used by a significant part of the model transformation community.

section.title: Development using COTS approach
section.para: As we position the compiler as a transformation, it appears thatrpart of it may be reused for different purposes. For example, we may want to constructs a compiler, an interpreter or tools that transform the transformation program.
The organization of eclipse in projects leads us to create many Eclipse projects: one project per COTS.
COTS is the general approach used for transformation management.

section.title: Tool choices
section.para: The following tools were chosen to develop the BasicMTL compiler prototype.

listitem.para: Ecli.se IDE: as a global and extendable programming framework.
Java: target language for the first implementation of the compiler. Chosen for its correct connection to the state of the art repositories (ex: mdr)
Antlr: helps for the text parsing of the concrete surface syntax
Ant: scripting for build process which is multiplatform and tool independent.
Log4j: powerful log system
JUnit: unitary testing in complement to some shell script running duping the night
Objectering + java code generation: for modelisation and code generation of the first version of the compiler from the AST specification.
